funcs.name: checkdate
funcs.desc: Checks the validity of the date formed by the arguments. A date is considered valid if each parameter is properly defined.

return.desc: Returns TRUE if the date given is valid; otherwise returns FALSE.

args.name: month
args.desc: The month is between 1 and 12 inclusive.

args.name: day
args.desc: The day is within the allowed number of days for the given month. Leap years are taken into consideration.

args.name: year
args.desc: The year is between 1 and 32767 inclusive.

return.desc: Returns a new DateTime instance or FALSE on failure.

funcs.name: date_default_timezone_get
funcs.desc:
In order of preference, this function returns the default timezone by:

Reading the timezone set using the date_default_timezone_set() function (if any)

Reading the TZ environment variable (if non empty) (Prior to PHP 5.3.0)

Reading the value of the date.timezone ini option (if set)

Querying the host operating system (if supported and allowed by the OS)

If none of the above succeed, date_default_timezone_get() will return a default timezone of UTC.

return.desc: Returns a string.

funcs.name: date_default_timezone_set
funcs.desc:
date_default_timezone_set() sets the default timezone used by all date/time functions.

Since PHP 5.1.0 (when the date/time functions were rewritten), every call to a date/time function will generate a E_NOTICE if the timezone isn't valid, and/or a E_WARNING message if using the system settings or the TZ environment variable.

Instead of using this function to set the default timezone in your script, you can also use the INI setting date.timezone to set the default timezone.

return.desc: This function returns FALSE if the timezone_identifier isn't valid, or TRUE otherwise.

args.name: name
args.desc: The timezone identifier, like UTC or Europe/Lisbon. The list of valid identifiers is available in the List of Supported Timezones.

return.desc: Returns array with information about the parsed date on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: date
args.desc: Date in format accepted by strtotime().

return.desc: Returns array on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: ts
args.desc: Timestamp.

args.name: latitude
args.desc: Latitude in degrees.

args.name: longitude
args.desc: Longitude in degrees.

funcs.name: date_sunrise
funcs.desc: date_sunrise() returns the sunrise time for a given day (specified as a timestamp) and location.

return.desc: Returns the sunrise time in a specified format on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: timestamp
args.desc: The timestamp of the day from which the sunrise time is taken.

args.name: format
args.desc: format constants constant description example SUNFUNCS_RET_STRING returns the result as string 16:46 SUNFUNCS_RET_DOUBLE returns the result as float 16.78243132 SUNFUNCS_RET_TIMESTAMP returns the result as integer (timestamp) 1095034606

args.name: latitude
args.desc: Defaults to North, pass in a negative value for South. See also: date.default_latitude

args.name: longitude
args.desc: Defaults to East, pass in a negative value for West. See also: date.default_longitude

args.name: zenith
args.desc: Default: date.sunrise_zenith

args.name: gmt_offset
args.desc: Specified in hours.

funcs.name: date_sunset
funcs.desc: date_sunset() returns the sunset time for a given day (specified as a timestamp) and location.

return.desc: Returns the sunset time in a specified format on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: timestamp
args.desc: The timestamp of the day from which the sunset time is taken.

args.name: format
args.desc: format constants constant description example SUNFUNCS_RET_STRING returns the result as string 16:46 SUNFUNCS_RET_DOUBLE returns the result as float 16.78243132 SUNFUNCS_RET_TIMESTAMP returns the result as integer (timestamp) 1095034606

args.name: latitude
args.desc: Defaults to North, pass in a negative value for South. See also: date.default_latitude

args.name: longitude
args.desc: Defaults to East, pass in a negative value for West. See also: date.default_longitude

args.name: zenith
args.desc: Default: date.sunset_zenith

args.name: gmt_offset
args.desc: Specified in hours.

funcs.name: date
funcs.desc: Returns a string formatted according to the given format string using the given integer timestamp or the current time if no timestamp is given. In other words, timestamp is optional and defaults to the value of time().

return.desc: Returns a formatted date string. If a non-numeric value is used for timestamp, FALSE is returned and an E_WARNING level error is emitted.

funcs.name: getdate
funcs.desc: Returns an associative array containing the date information of the timestamp, or the current local time if no timestamp is given.

args.name: timestamp
args.desc: The optional timestamp parameter is an integer Unix timestamp that defaults to the current local time if a timestamp is not given. In other words, it defaults to the value of time().

funcs.name: gettimeofday
funcs.desc: This is an interface to gettimeofday(2). It returns an associative array containing the data returned from the system call.

return.desc:
By default an array is returned. If return_float is set, then a float is returned.

Array keys: "sec" - seconds since the Unix Epoch "usec" - microseconds "minuteswest" - minutes west of Greenwich "dsttime" - type of dst correction

args.name: return_float
args.desc: When set to TRUE, a float instead of an array is returned.

funcs.name: gmdate
funcs.desc: Identical to the date() function except that the time returned is Greenwich Mean Time (GMT).

return.desc: Returns a formatted date string. If a non-numeric value is used for timestamp, FALSE is returned and an E_WARNING level error is emitted.

args.name: format
args.desc: The format of the outputted date string. See the formatting options for the date() function.

args.name: timestamp
args.desc: The optional timestamp parameter is an integer Unix timestamp that defaults to the current local time if a timestamp is not given. In other words, it defaults to the value of time().

funcs.name: gmmktime
funcs.desc:
Identical to mktime() except the passed parameters represents a GMT date. gmmktime() internally uses mktime() so only times valid in derived local time can be used.

Like mktime(), arguments may be left out in order from right to left, with any omitted arguments being set to the current corresponding GMT value.

return.desc: Returns a integer Unix timestamp.

args.name: hour
args.desc: The hour

args.name: minute
args.desc: The minute

args.name: second
args.desc: The second

args.name: month
args.desc: The month

args.name: day
args.desc: The day

args.name: year
args.desc: The year

funcs.name: gmstrftime
funcs.desc: Behaves the same as strftime() except that the time returned is Greenwich Mean Time (GMT). For example, when run in Eastern Standard Time (GMT -0500), the first line below prints "Dec 31 1998 20:00:00", while the second prints "Jan 01 1999 01:00:00".

return.desc: Returns a string formatted according to the given format string using the given timestamp or the current local time if no timestamp is given. Month and weekday names and other language dependent strings respect the current locale set with setlocale().

args.name: format
args.desc: See description in strftime().

args.name: timestamp
args.desc: The optional timestamp parameter is an integer Unix timestamp that defaults to the current local time if a timestamp is not given. In other words, it defaults to the value of time().

funcs.name: idate
funcs.desc:
Returns a number formatted according to the given format string using the given integer timestamp or the current local time if no timestamp is given. In other words, timestamp is optional and defaults to the value of time().

Unlike the function date(), idate() accepts just one char in the format parameter.

return.desc:
Returns an integer.

As idate() always returns an integer and as they can't start with a "0", idate() may return fewer digits than you would expect. See the example below.

args.name: format
args.desc: The following characters are recognized in the format parameter string format character Description B Swatch Beat/Internet Time d Day of the month h Hour (12 hour format) H Hour (24 hour format) i Minutes I (uppercase i) returns 1 if DST is activated, 0 otherwise L (uppercase l) returns 1 for leap year, 0 otherwise m Month number s Seconds t Days in current month U Seconds since the Unix Epoch - January 1 1970 00:00:00 UTC - this is the same as time() w Day of the week (0 on Sunday) W ISO-8601 week number of year, weeks starting on Monday y Year (1 or 2 digits - check note below) Y Year (4 digits) z Day of the year Z Timezone offset in seconds

args.name: timestamp
args.desc: The optional timestamp parameter is an integer Unix timestamp that defaults to the current local time if a timestamp is not given. In other words, it defaults to the value of time().

funcs.name: localtime
funcs.desc: The localtime() function returns an array identical to that of the structure returned by the C function call.

args.name: timestamp
args.desc: The optional timestamp parameter is an integer Unix timestamp that defaults to the current local time if a timestamp is not given. In other words, it defaults to the value of time().

args.name: is_associative
args.desc:
If set to FALSE or not supplied then the array is returned as a regular, numerically indexed array. If the argument is set to TRUE then localtime() returns an associative array containing all the different elements of the structure returned by the C function call to localtime. The names of the different keys of the associative array are as follows:

"tm_sec" - seconds "tm_min" - minutes "tm_hour" - hour "tm_mday" - day of the month Months are from 0 (Jan) to 11 (Dec) and days of the week are from 0 (Sun) to 6 (Sat). "tm_mon" - month of the year, starting with 0 for January "tm_year" - Years since 1900 "tm_wday" - Day of the week "tm_yday" - Day of the year "tm_isdst" - Is daylight savings time in effect

funcs.name: microtime
funcs.desc: microtime() returns the current Unix timestamp with microseconds. This function is only available on operating systems that support the gettimeofday() system call.

args.name: get_as_float
args.desc:
When called without the optional argument, this function returns the string "msec sec" where sec is the current time measured in the number of seconds since the Unix Epoch (0:00:00 January 1, 1970 GMT), and msec is the microseconds part. Both portions of the string are returned in units of seconds.

If the optional get_as_float is set to TRUE then a float (in seconds) is returned.

funcs.name: mktime
funcs.desc:
Returns the Unix timestamp corresponding to the arguments given. This timestamp is a long integer containing the number of seconds between the Unix Epoch (January 1 1970 00:00:00 GMT) and the time specified.

Arguments may be left out in order from right to left; any arguments thus omitted will be set to the current value according to the local date and time.

return.desc: mktime() returns the Unix timestamp of the arguments given. If the arguments are invalid, the function returns FALSE (before PHP 5.1 it returned -1).

args.name: hour
args.desc: The number of the hour.

args.name: minute
args.desc: The number of the minute.

args.name: second
args.desc: The number of seconds past the minute.

args.name: month
args.desc: The number of the month.

args.name: day
args.desc: The number of the day.

args.name: year
args.desc: The number of the year, may be a two or four digit value, with values between 0-69 mapping to 2000-2069 and 70-100 to 1970-2000. On systems where time_t is a 32bit signed integer, as most common today, the valid range for year is somewhere between 1901 and 2038. However, before PHP 5.1.0 this range was limited from 1970 to 2038 on some systems (e.g. Windows).

funcs.name: strftime
funcs.desc:
Format the time and/or date according to locale settings. Month and weekday names and other language-dependent strings respect the current locale set with setlocale().

Not all conversion specifiers may be supported by your C library, in which case they will not be supported by PHP's strftime(). Additionally, not all platforms support negative timestamps, so your date range may be limited to no earlier than the Unix epoch. This means that %e, %T, %R and, %D (and possibly others) - as well as dates prior to Jan 1, 1970 - will not work on Windows, some Linux distributions, and a few other operating systems. For Windows systems, a complete overview of supported conversion specifiers can be found at MSDN.

return.desc: Returns a string formatted according format using the given timestamp or the current local time if no timestamp is given. Month and weekday names and other language-dependent strings respect the current locale set with setlocale().

funcs.name: strptime
funcs.desc:
strptime() returns an array with the date parsed, or FALSE on error.

Month and weekday names and other language dependent strings respect the current locale set with setlocale() (LC_TIME).

return.desc:
Returns an array or FALSE on failure.

The following parameters are returned in the array parameters Description "tm_sec" Seconds after the minute (0-61) "tm_min" Minutes after the hour (0-59) "tm_hour" Hour since midnight (0-23) "tm_mday" Day of the month (1-31) "tm_mon" Months since January (0-11) "tm_year" Years since 1900 "tm_wday" Days since Sunday (0-6) "tm_yday" Days since January 1 (0-365) "unparsed" the date part which was not recognized using the specified format

args.name: date
args.desc: The string to parse (e.g. returned from strftime()).

args.name: format
args.desc:
The format used in date (e.g. the same as used in strftime()). Note that some of the format options available to strftime() may not have any effect within strptime(); the exact subset that are supported will vary based on the operating system and C library in use.

For more information about the format options, read the strftime() page.

return.desc: Returns a timestamp on success, FALSE otherwise. Previous to PHP 5.1.0, this function would return -1 on failure.

args.name: input
args.desc: Date and Time Formats.

args.name: timestamp
args.desc: The timestamp which is used as a base for the calculation of relative dates.

funcs.name: time
funcs.desc: Returns the current time measured in the number of seconds since the Unix Epoch (January 1 1970 00:00:00 GMT).

return.desc: Returns time zone name on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: abbr
args.desc: Time zone abbreviation.

args.name: gmtoffset
args.desc: Offset from GMT in seconds. Defaults to -1 which means that first found time zone corresponding to abbr is returned. Otherwise exact offset is searched and only if not found then the first time zone with any offset is returned.

args.name: isdst
args.desc: Daylight saving time indicator. Defaults to -1, which means that whether the time zone has daylight saving or not is not taken into consideration when searching. If this is set to 1, then the gmtOffset is assumed to be an offset with daylight saving in effect; if 0, then gmtOffset is assumed to be an offset without daylight saving in effect. If abbr doesn't exist then the time zone is searched solely by the gmtOffset and isdst.

classes.name: DateTime

funcs.name: add
funcs.desc: Add an interval to a datetime object

return.desc: Returns the DateTime object for method chaining

args.name: interval
args.desc: DateInterval object containing the time to add.

funcs.name: createFromFormat
funcs.desc: Parse a date according to a format and create a DateTime object

return.desc: Returns a new DateTime instance or FALSE on failure.

args.name: format
args.desc: DateTime format specifier

args.name: time
args.desc: Date and time to parse

args.name: timezone
args.desc: DateTimeZone for the given time

funcs.name: diff
funcs.desc: Find the interval between two DateTime objects

return.desc: Returns a DateInterval object representing the distance between two times

args.name: datetime2
args.desc: DateTime object to compare agains

args.name: absolute
args.desc: Whether to return absolute difference

funcs.name: format
funcs.desc: Procedural style string date_format ( DateTime $object , string $format ) Returns date formatted according to given format.

return.desc: Returns the formatted date string on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: format
args.desc: DateTime object returned by date_create()

funcs.name: getLastErrors
funcs.desc: Returns the last errors encountered by the datetime extension

return.desc: Vector of error messages

funcs.name: getOffset
funcs.desc: Procedural style int date_offset_get ( DateTime $object ) Returns the timezone offset.

return.desc: Returns the timezone offset in seconds from UTC on success or FALSE on failure.

funcs.name: getTimestamp
funcs.desc: Returns the unix timestamp representing the date.

return.desc: Epoch representing the datetime object

funcs.name: getTimezone
funcs.desc: Procedural style DateTimeZone date_timezone_get ( DateTime $object ) Return time zone relative to given DateTime.

return.desc: Returns a DateTimeZone object on success or FALSE on failure.

funcs.name: modify
funcs.desc: Procedural style DateTime date_modify ( DateTime $object , string $modify ) Alter the timestamp of a DateTime object by incrementing or decrementing in a format accepted by strtotime().

return.desc: Returns the modified DateTime object or FALSE on failure.

args.name: modify
args.desc: DateTime object returned by date_create(). The function modifies this object.

funcs.name: setDate
funcs.desc: Procedural style DateTime date_date_set ( DateTime $object , int $year , int $month , int $day ) Resets the current date of the DateTime object to a different date.

return.desc: Returns the modified DateTime object or FALSE on failure.

args.name: year
args.desc: DateTime object returned by date_create(). The function modifies this object.

args.name: month
args.desc: Year of the date.

args.name: day
args.desc: Month of the date.

funcs.name: setISODate
funcs.desc: Procedural style DateTime date_isodate_set ( DateTime $object , int $year , int $week [, int $day = 1 ] ) Set a date according to the ISO 8601 standard - using weeks and day offsets rather than specific dates.

return.desc: Returns the modified DateTime object or FALSE on failure.

args.name: year
args.desc: DateTime object returned by date_create(). The function modifies this object.

args.name: week
args.desc: Year of the date.

args.name: day
args.desc: Week of the date.

funcs.name: setTime
funcs.desc: Procedural style DateTime date_time_set ( DateTime $object , int $hour , int $minute [, int $second = 0 ] ) Resets the current time of the DateTime object to a different time.

return.desc: Returns the modified DateTime object or FALSE on failure.

args.name: hour
args.desc: DateTime object returned by date_create(). The function modifies this object.

args.name: minute
args.desc: Hour of the time.

args.name: second
args.desc: Minute of the time.

funcs.name: setTimestamp
funcs.desc: Set the DateTime object according to the timestamp provided

return.desc: Returns the DateTime object for method chaining

args.name: unixtimestamp
args.desc: Unix timestamp to update the DateTime object to.

funcs.name: setTimezone
funcs.desc: Procedural style DateTime date_timezone_set ( DateTime $object , DateTimeZone $timezone )

return.desc: Returns the modified DateTime object or FALSE on failure.

args.name: timezone
args.desc: DateTime object returned by date_create(). The function modifies this object.

funcs.name: sub
funcs.desc: Subtract an interval from a datetime object

return.desc: Returns the DateTime object for method chaining

args.name: interval
args.desc: DateInterval object containing the time to subtract.

classes.name: DateTimeZone

funcs.name: getLocation
funcs.desc: Returns location information for a timezone

return.desc: Array containing location information about timezone.

funcs.name: getName
funcs.desc: Procedural style string timezone_name_get ( void ) Returns the name of the timezone.

return.desc: One of timezones.

funcs.name: getOffset
funcs.desc: Procedural style int timezone_offset_get ( DateTimeZone $object , DateTime $datetime ) This function returns the offset to GMT for the date/time specified in the datetime parameter. The GMT offset is calculated with the timezone information contained in the DateTimeZone object being used.

return.desc: Returns time zone offset in seconds on success or FALSE on failure.

args.name: datetime
args.desc: DateTimeZone object returned by timezone_open()

funcs.name: getTransitions
funcs.desc: Procedural style array timezone_transitions_get ( DateTimeZone $object [, int $timestamp_begin [, int $timestamp_end ]] )

return.desc: Returns numerically indexed array containing associative array with all transitions on success or FALSE on failure.

funcs.name: listAbbreviations
funcs.desc: Procedural style array timezone_abbreviations_list ( void )

return.desc: Returns array on success or FALSE on failure.

funcs.name: listIdentifiers
funcs.desc: Procedural style array timezone_identifiers_list ([ int $what = DateTimeZone::ALL [, string $country = NULL ]] )

return.desc: Returns array on success or FALSE on failure.

classes.name: DateInterval

funcs.name: __construct
funcs.desc: Creates a new DateInterval object

funcs.name: __get
funcs.desc: Retreives interval partials (y, m, d, etc...)

return.desc: Number of years, months, days, hours, minutes, seconds, or total days for DateInterval, or true/false for date inversion.

args.name: member
args.desc: One of 'y', 'm', 'd', 'h', 'i', 's', 'invert', or 'days'.  All other vales will return null and throw undefined property notice.

funcs.name: __set
funcs.desc: Sets interval partials (y, m, d, etc...)

return.desc: Always returns NULL.

args.name: member
args.desc: One of 'y', 'm', 'd', 'h', 'i', 's', 'invert', or 'days'.  All other vales will throw undefined property notice and ignore value.

args.name: value
args.desc: Either a boolean for 'invert', or a number.

funcs.name: createFromDateString
funcs.desc: Sets up a DateInterval from the relative parts of the string

return.desc: Returns a new DateInterval instance.

args.name: time
args.desc: A date with relative parts. Specifically, the relative formats supported by the parser used for strtotime() and DateTime will be used to construct the DateInterval.

funcs.name: format
funcs.desc: Formats the interval

return.desc: Returns the formatted interval.

args.name: format
args.desc: DateInterval format specifier.
